thread.section_title: Oklahoma Sooners News - Sports News for Dallas, Texas
thread.title: How Texas' D-line took advantage of OU senior lineman's repeated mistake to make life tough for Sooners' QB Mayfield
thread.title_full: How Texas' D-line took advantage of OU senior lineman's repeated mistake to make life tough for Sooners' QB Mayfield | Dallas Morning News

author: Bill Nichols
title: How Texas' D-line took advantage of OU senior lineman's repeated mistake to make life tough for Sooners' QB Mayfield
text:
Coming off a 50-7 loss to TCU, Texas was 1-4 and seemingly reeling, and coach Charlie Strong was under fire with his team off to its worst start in 59 years.
But Saturday, it was the Longhorns who brought the pressure. They went all out on Oklahoma, regularly sending at least one extra defender at quarterback Baker Mayfield.
The aggressive approach resulted in six sacks, one fewer than Texas posted in its first five games, in a 24-17 upset of the 10th-ranked Sooners.
The pressure confounded the Sooners early. They managed only 15 yards in the first quarter and 85 in the first half.
"It wasn't like they were outmanning us," Mayfield said. "They were bringing five-man pressures inside. They would bring a different guy here and there, and early on it got to us."
The Longhorns surpassed their previous season high in sacks -- three against Oklahoma State -- with four in the first half.
Not bad for a Texas team that ranked eighth in the Big 12 in total defense and ninth in pass defense.
Several players said that Strong's simple message during the week -- "We're going to win" -- inspired confidence.
"That's all we needed to hear," said freshman linebacker Malik Jefferson from Mesquite Poteet. "We were focused, everybody bonded, and we knew what we needed to do. That just shows you how good we can be when we put our minds to it."
The Longhorns were tipped off by OU tackle Josiah St. John changing his stance on pass plays.
"That's on me," St. John said. "I'm a senior, and that's something I can't do. Nothing else really to say about it."
The Longhorns dominated the line of scrimmage. They limited OU to 67 rushing yards on 37 carries for a 1.8-yard average.
OU's inability to run played into UT's hands. With the Sooners dazed, the Longhorns applied a similar physical approach on offense, running for 313 yards. They took a 14-0 lead and limited OU to a field goal in the first half.
Although the Sooners put together drives of 87 and 75 yards in the second half, Texas' defense took charge down the stretch. After Samaje Perine's 1-yard touchdown cut UT's lead to 24-17 with eight minutes left, the Sooners got the ball back with 6:05 remaining.
But Mayfield got sacked twice -- by Ford and Naashon Hughes -- and Oklahoma punted. The Longhorns then ran out the clock.
Jefferson led UT with two sacks, causing a loss of 12 yards. Poona Ford had 11/2 sacks for minus-13 yards.
"It was just a different mind-set, and all week long we talked about we were going to pressure," Strong said. "I guarantee you we pressured them early every snap. Maybe played three downs of space defense, but other than that the pressure was coming because we wanted to get the ball out of the quarterback's hands, make him make bad decisions and stop the run."
